description:
Late 14th century, as Middle English attempten, from Old French atempter, from Latin attemptō (“I try, solicit”), from ad (“to”) + temptare, more correctly tentare (“to try”); see tempt.
The noun is from the 1530s, the sense "an assault on somebody's life, assassination attempt" (French attentat) is from 1580.

entries.meaning: The action of trying at something. [1530]
An assault or attack, especially an assassination attempt. [1580]
The action of trying at something. [1530]
examples: We made an attempt to cross the stream, but didn't manage.
This poem is much better than the feeble attempt of mine.
No matter how many failed attempts we made, we maintained a positive attitude and tried again and again until we succeeded.

entries.meaning: An assault or attack, especially an assassination attempt. [1580]

verbs.description: attempt (third-person singular simple present attempts, present participle attempting, simple past and past participle attempted)

examples: I attempted to sing, but my throat was too hoarse.
to attempt an escape from prison
A group of 80 budding mountaineers attempted Kilimanjaro, but 30 of them didn't make it to the top.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To try to move, by entreaty, by afflictions, or by temptations; to tempt.
(archaic) To try to win, subdue, or overcome.
examples: one who attempts the virtue of a woman

entries.meaning: (archaic) To attack; to make an effort or attack upon; to try to take by force.
